The pacing in this game is entirely off putting. It starts slow, stays slow, and by the time you have a train network fully established across Europe, you’re not even halfway to the end-game condition in money. Every time a player delivers a contract, the game stops so the player can identify the demands of his new card and see what can be done this turn to help accomplish it. This game needs some serious house rules to make it playable, at which point you may as well play any one of a number of different train games that have inherently solved these problems and are far better.

Initial Rating: 6.0 (May 2023)

My desire to play Eurorails was low, but only because it's a long game and you have to draw on the board (which I dislike). Around 10 years ago, I played Iron Dragon, and we didn't finish it. After finally playing Eurorails, I can say it's a fun game, but we played the short version and it still took several hours to end.

Eurorails' rules are easy to teach as they are very straightforward. You can explain them in under 6 minutes. Playtime is around 5 hours.

The theme of Eurorails, as the name suggests, revolves around building railways across Europe and then picking up and delivering goods. I'm not a fan of railroad games, but the theme works well in conjunction with the game's mechanisms.

The game's components aren't the best, but you have to keep in mind that this is a 1990 game. The game board is sturdy, but I dislike having to draw on it as I feel it will degrade the game eventually. The game comes with lots of small tokens that are hard to keep organized in the tray, so it's better to bag them. It has paper money. The game is now VERY expensive, and I have a new copy, but none of my friends is willing to pay what it cost me.

When a friend was explaining the rules, I thought I was going to be very bored by the game, but I was pleasantly surprised. Even though the game's decisions aren't very deep, I was engaged all the time. I was even against ending the game early, as proposed by a friend. The goal is to be the richest player at the end, and the game ends when a player has accumulated 250 million dollars and connected all but one of the major cities in the network. On a turn, players can move their locomotive on the board a certain number of spaces. Locomotives can be upgraded to be faster and to handle more goods at the same time. Once a locomotive passes over a city or town, the player can load their train with the goods produced in that location. Players have 3 demand cards at all times, and the idea is to deliver the goods shown in the cards to the corresponding cities. After this, players can build infrastructure. The game is fun and engaging, but its complexity doesn't lie in deep decisions. Instead, there is a lot of information thrown at players, so initially, the turns were slow as players planned the best routes to build. I generally don't like pick-up-and-deliver games, but I had fun playing Eurorails. I enjoyed the puzzle-like nature of finding the most efficient routes and optimizing the deliveries. I cannot deny that. As I mentioned before, I don't feel the game's decisions are hard to process. The hardest thing is to create an effective network, but that depends on the contracts. Therefore, players familiar with the game will have a HUGE advantage. There are cities in the game that allow for an easier time when delivering, and there are cities that appear more often in the demand cards. Having this knowledge is important to create an effective network, but that knowledge comes with experience playing the game. Similarly, from my perusal of the deck (after we finished), it seems that some cities are not worth connecting as they have very few demand cards and are far away from anything. This doesn't seem balanced, and only hard-earned knowledge can mitigate this.

The luck factor is high in the game. While players have control over their route choices and the goods they pick up, they don't have much control over the cards they draw. In our game, the player who won often discarded demand cards until he found cards that had synergy between themselves. As the cards appear randomly, this can happen quickly or slowly. Besides this, there are some event cards that are unbalanced and (probably) affect only 1 player at random. For example, a player was about to deliver a certain type of goods, and just because of an event, that good's value increased for the next delivery. This wasn't planned; it just happened, and I dislike this. Other events are very harsh (you can get infrastructure destroyed just because), and it's pure luck whether you get hit by one of them or not. In summary, I heavily dislike the random nature of the events, even if they do mimic real-life events. They aren't fair or balanced at all.

Best with 3 fast players, with more the downtime is too much AND the playtime is also too much. I cannot imagine playing a 5-player game.

The replay value of Eurorails is quite high. Each game will be different due to the cards and the way players build infrastructure.

Bottom line, Eurorails is a fun game that offers enjoyment and engagement. It surprised me that its rules were concise and easy to grasp. Sadly, it's too long for what it offers, and the luck factor is also very high. I also heavily dislike that I have to write on the board, as I feel it will eventually damage the game. I will sell my copy of the game as soon as possible, but I confess that Eurorails is better than expected, and I would like to play it again if only it wasn't so long.

Pleasant enough. I enjoy pick up and deliver type games, there’s something satisfying about them. But it goes long, and not much happens.

Another good entry in the crayon rails series. Comments from the original Empire Builder title apply here as well: this is a mathy train network building game that is a good deal more fine-grained that most modern game design. Nonetheless, it's a unique experience that isn't really outmoded by any modern title. The fine-grained economics and spartan emphasis on route-drawing work well with the game as it's designed, and there's just something nice about building a new rail system.

I'm no series expert, but my one play of this map was just as good as any other in the series. Neat rules with the Chunnel and ferries. Map seems reasonably well-balanced.
